course.subject: LANG
course.name: French: World Language and Culture
course.description: This is a course for learners with no previous knowledge of French. It aims to promote an international perspective by helping them acquire the basics of French. By the end of the course, students will be able to communicate appropriately in French on a variety of everyday topics, and have an overview of certain themes in French and Francophone culture which will enhance their knowledge of Europe and the world.

reviews.author: vtsui
reviews.title: Many tests
reviews.comment_content:
common communication vocabulary
time, number, telephone number, verbs (e.g. aller, comprend...)

mainly use google translate in study
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor always wants us to learn more so many vocabulary.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is a little bit harsh.
I am at the 7th in class --> B+ only
reviews.comment_workload:
many tests and quiz

There are two listening tests, three reading tests, two writing tests, one oral test, three group presentations and one individual presentation.
There also one final exam in the last lesson.

Attendance is needed. If you miss a lesson, then you need to do extra homework but you marks still be deducted.

There are one essay before final examination. You need to choose the topic by yourself about culture in France or France-speaking countries.
Group presentations are also about introducing a France-speaking country, sports popular in France and culture also.

reviews.author: c:
reviews.title: Best lang course in ust
reviews.comment_content:
Reading: reading comprehension, the first reading quiz is quite hard as you need to understand the whole french passage with just one month of study
Writing: write about family member, friend, introduce yourself
Listening: numbers are the most difficult to listen
Oral: similar topics to writing

Actually not much teaching content, so the scope of quiz and final is reasonable.
reviews.comment_teaching: Mark is the best lang instructor, it's like studying English back in secondary. You would enjoy it if you really want to learn a new language.
reviews.comment_grading: Quite good, should be 40% students got A range.
reviews.comment_workload:
Ungraded homework almost every week
4 ungraded group presentations

Reading quiz: 1
Writing quiz: 2
Listening quiz: 1
Oral quiz: 1

Culture essay

Final:
Reading + Writing
Listening and Oral tested before study break

reviews.author: cookiemonster
reviews.comment_content:
VERY culture-focused learning of the French language. I feel like I know a lot about France now without actually having gone there. Because it's a very discussion based course, the structure is somewhat messy. However, you find that you still learn quite a bit regarding basic French - numbers, common phrases, months, days of the week, some verbs, etc.

At the end of the semester he hosts a wine and cheese party for the class.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very nice professor. His attitude sometimes makes him seem more like a friend than a professor. Very understanding if you need to send in homework a bit late. He often has discussions in class.

However, the course is a bit unstructured. Some may prefer this as opposed to a rigid structure, but I personally found it a little messy.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading, should be fine as long as you put the work in.
- 40% Final exam
- 40% Tests and presentations (throughout the semester)
- 20% cultural expose (a cultural essay written in English about any French topic)

As with most LANG courses, you can't miss more than 5 or you fail the course automatically.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload a little towards the high side, but it doesn't take long to complete.

4 cultural presentations in class done as a group, can be done very quickly amongst groupmates.

Homework is OPTIONAL. He doesn't mind if you don't submit it.

3-4 tests throughout the semester (oral, written, comprehension, listening). Moderate difficulty.

reviews.author: supermin
reviews.title: Easy in general, easier if you have background in basic french
reviews.comment_content:
The course itself is aimed towards people who do not have any background in french language. You learn basic grammar and vocabulary, and also learn about French culture (cuisines, landmarks, significant history,etc)

You need to buy Panorama french textbook, as he uses it during the lecture.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teacher is very witty and kind, and helps you to learn the language effectively. Though at times the chat between teacher and student runs off topic, it's still centered around french culture and France in general.

He's fluent in both french and english, and seems to know a few cantonese phrases as he jokingly says them in appropriate times.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading itself is pretty lax. As long as you do assignments/projects as requested, you will get a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite a bit, there are little assessments (vocab, listening, speaking, writing) every once in a few weeks, and you need to do a group presentation every 3 weeks on a specific topic (french holidays, leisure activity, food, etc).

Homework is optional. It's not graded.

The only assignment that may take some time is the final written assignment, a 900-1100 english essay you need to write on a specific French topic. Rest takes less than 30 minutes.

reviews.author: blahblu
reviews.title: uh
reviews.comment_content:
teaches first two chapters of panorama, plus need to do presentation on french culture in groups you form

some grammar taught, but not organized, so you don't really know what's happening but suddenly you discover that everything is on the exam

have to write a research paper, you can decide on your own topic

reviews.author: kentanggoreng
reviews.comment_content: Basic French words and grammar. Present tense, did not touch past or present. A lot of emphasis towards French culture as well. It was not enough French language and too much French culture in my opinion, but some people liked it that way.
reviews.comment_teaching: Mark is such a nice guy. He knows so many languages, he knows what you're going through as a new learner. He's patient and he would explain the content to you really slowly too.
reviews.comment_grading: Very lenient grading. It is not curved. >75% overall performance gets A range, which is not that hard.
reviews.comment_workload:
A lot of cultural presentations. Once in every other week. You have to form a group and present about French territories, food, sports and hobbies. Too much, in my opinion.
On the weeks you don't have presentation, he gives you homeworks. There were oral, writing, listening and speaking exams too. And you need to write a thousand word essay at the end of the course.

reviews.author: hihello
reviews.title: Good grade, but not counted towards anything.
reviews.comment_content:
I took this course to raise my GPA so I could qualify for exchange. My plan worked.

Yet be mindful that this course does not count towards anything (not SSC, not CC)

The content is pretty elementary, very basic. You will be taught verbs etre and avoir, how to conjugate them in the present tense.

Apart from vocab, verbs, grammar, you will also be taught about the French culture. I found this portion of the classes quite interesting, and wished there was more in-depth discussion about French culture, way of life, politics, etc.

Attendance is compulsory and there is no leeway to miss any classes.

It is required to buy the textbook, but a pdf version is available online.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Mark is a nice, cheerful guy. He is very travelled, very cultured, very mature, and very worldly.

He is understanding if you have to miss a class, and makes exceptions. Rules don't have to be carved in stone.

He creates a positive learning environment and is cheerful. His classes were a break from the other hectic courses I had.
reviews.comment_grading:
Even though most students do not have French background, content is very easy, so many students in class will do quite well. It will be quite competitive to get the top grades e.g. A+.

Ensure that you get near full marks for ALL work assigned, from assignments to the final exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
- presentation of two  topics chosen by you (food/ place/ festival/ etc)
- assignments (e.g. piece of writing, voice recording of your oral presentation)
- midterm
- final

Workload is very manageable.

reviews.author: Chin
reviews.comment_content: The course is an introduction to French and the French culture. Mark did not teach us the phonetics intentionally in a systematic way, but rather taught it in an integrated way when we encounter a particular word. Grammar-wise, the present tense and a little bit of the future tense were covered. The mandatory textbook is Panorama (only the first unit is covered), and Mark will also give handouts for some lessons in Bienvenue en France, plus some extra materials which are generally quite useful. Quite an amount of vocab will be encountered in class and if you work hard enough, you will definite learn a lot.
reviews.comment_teaching: Mark is definitely an excellent teacher and I would give out A+ if there is an option for that. He is a language master, I would say, being able to speak multiple languages and still learning Russian. He really knows a lot about the things (historical/cultural/geographical) behind some linguistic manifestations. In terms of French culture, he is very knowledgeable and passionate, he would be able to comment on almost every subject that we talked about in the cultural presentations. And at the end of semester, he brought us French wine, cheese and bread for tasting.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is absolutely fair and transparent. Mark gives back our work (quizzes, writings even where we lost our marks in the oral task) for each assessment with detailed grading. The class is quite competitive though, there are quite a few GBUS students who have learned some basic French and some of them will get really high marks in the quizzes. I personally do not have any prior learning experience of French but I consider myself as having the talent for learning languages and worked reasonably hard and got a satisfactory grade. The exams are not too hard in general, given that you pay attention in class, finish the assignments and review accordingly.
reviews.comment_workload: Tbh, the workload is heavier than average UST courses, but it's definitely worth it. Presentations every 2 weeks, although it's not-graded, I felt a need to do the presentations well because Mark is such a passionate teacher otherwise I feel guilty for disappointing him. There was 1 reading and writing final, 1 oral final, and 1 listening final. Throughout the semester, there were about 4 assignments which we needed to submit but not counted towards our final grade and also about 4 assessments on speaking, listening, reading, writing.

reviews.author: BH
reviews.title: Good grade course and good experience to learn french
reviews.comment_content: It is a basic class for french, the content includes the basic grammar, vocabs and conversation with different topics. Quite interesting if you love france because it also introduce a lot of culture stuffs. The class requires the textbook which i think is quite expensive, but if you want to continue the french study then i suggest you to buy coz the fee charging french course supported by the language center use the same book. Also, Mark would give out a lot of handouts to us for teaching. For a begin of learning french, the content is not that difficult and suitable for beginners.
reviews.comment_teaching: Mark is a very nice guy and a good french teacher. He taught us a lot of vocabs which related to the topics and provide a lot of information about France as a local. Also, he is a talkative person, he can chat with the student even out of the class. Compare with other french teachers, he is funny and hilarious so that the class would not be boring at all. At the end of the semester he would bring a lot of wine and cheese to the class and let us try. Very happy and good experience for summing up the course.
reviews.comment_grading: Good grade. I think i am the average one in the class but still got B. Note that there are many exchanges and people who have learnt french in the class, but i still got B so I think it is very good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: A little bit heavy workload. We have to do group presentation about the culture in France biweekly. No marks for those presentations but still learn a lot of stuffs in throughout the presentations. Many small quizzes and homework need to finish, but i think it's appropriate because it can make sure the students are catching up to the classes. All of them are not difficult, you can just spent half an hour to revise before the quizzes. Homework are quite easy if you go to class. One more essay need to be submitted at the end of the course. It is related to the culture but the specific topics are decided by ourselves. It has written final exam and listening and oral exam in class. Not that difficult as Mark give us the topics and all of them are the content we have learnt.

reviews.author: C.Y. Wang
reviews.title: Good grade if you well follow the lead
reviews.comment_teaching: He often goes off track, free styles or blows water, but he's nice as an instructor, you prolly just don't expect that your proficiency will be boosted by this course, it's not even pre-A1 level if you finish 4 courses like this, not flexing but I took this only to relax from the hectic ust daily life
reviews.comment_grading: Good grade course if you follow what he assigns you to do, pay some efforts and act proactively
reviews.comment_workload: Assignments / discussion board / presentation on regular basis;
